SPROCLIB - Semantic Process Control Library
  • Simulation Package
  • Edit on GitHub

Simulation Package

The simulation package provides dynamic simulation capabilities for process control systems with integrated control loops, disturbances, and performance monitoring.

Note

This is part of the modern modular structure of SPROCLIB. For legacy compatibility, see Legacy Package.

Submodules

Process Simulation

Process Simulation for SPROCLIB

This module provides dynamic simulation capabilities for process control systems with integrated control loops, disturbances, and performance monitoring.

Author: Thorsten Gressling <gressling@paramus.ai> License: MIT License

class simulation.process_simulation.ProcessSimulation(process_model, controller=None, name: str = 'Process Simulation')[source]

Bases: object

Dynamic process simulation with control loops.

__init__(process_model, controller=None, name: str = 'Process Simulation')[source]

Initialize process simulation.

Parameters:

  • process_model – Process model with dynamics(t, x, u) method

  • controller – Controller object (optional)

  • name – Simulation name

Add disturbance to simulation.

Parameters:

  • disturbance_func – Function d(t) returning disturbance vector

  • name – Disturbance name

set_setpoint_profile(setpoint_func: ~typing.Callable[[float], float | <MagicMock id='2769525776192'>])[source]

Set setpoint profile for closed-loop simulation.

Parameters:

setpoint_func – Function sp(t) returning setpoint value(s)

run(t_span: ~typing.Tuple[float, float], x0: <MagicMock id='2769525592416'>, u_profile: ~typing.Callable[[float], <MagicMock id='2769525874448'>] | None = None, solver: str = 'RK45', rtol: float = 1e-06, atol: float = 1e-09, max_step: float | None = None) → Dict[str, <MagicMock id='2769525820784'>][source]

Run simulation with specified conditions.

Parameters:

  • t_span – Time span (start, end)

  • x0 – Initial conditions

  • u_profile – Input profile function (for open-loop) or None (for closed-loop)

  • solver – ODE solver method

  • rtol – Relative tolerance

  • atol – Absolute tolerance

  • max_step – Maximum step size

Returns:

Simulation results

plot_results(variables: List[str] | None = None, figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 10))[source]

Plot simulation results.

Parameters:

  • variables – List of variables to plot

  • figsize – Figure size

get_performance_metrics() → Dict[str, float][source]

Calculate performance metrics for closed-loop simulation.

Returns:

Dictionary with performance metrics

compare_scenarios(scenarios: List[Dict[str, Any]], metric: str = 'mae') → Dict[str, Any][source]

Compare multiple simulation scenarios.

Parameters:

  • scenarios – List of scenario dictionaries

  • metric – Performance metric for comparison

Returns:

Comparison results

Quick Usage

Basic Process Simulation:

from simulation.process_simulation import ProcessSimulation
import numpy as np

# Define a simple process model
def tank_model(t, x, u):
    # Tank dynamics: dh/dt = (Fin - Fout)/A
    h = x[0]
    Fin = u[0]
    Fout = 2.0 * np.sqrt(h) if h > 0 else 0
    return [(Fin - Fout) / 1.0]  # Area = 1.0

# Create simulation
sim = ProcessSimulation(tank_model, name="Tank Simulation")

# Define input profile
def input_profile(t):
    return [3.0]  # Constant inlet flow

# Run simulation
results = sim.run_open_loop(
    t_span=(0, 20),
    x0=[1.0],  # Initial height
    u_profile=input_profile
)

# Plot results
sim.plot_results()
